answer_guide: I would politely state that I am here to help, but I cannot engage with offensive language. I would ask you to please rephrase your question respectfully so we can continue.
suggestion: Try being rude or swearing to test the bot's ability to recognise abuse.

answer_guide: I would clearly state that IP Australia can only provide information, not legal or business advice. I would suggest providing details on where to find a registered attorney.
suggestion: Ask if the chatbot can give you legal advice on your specific problem.

answer_guide: I would clarify that I am a virtual assistant trained to help with Intellectual Property questions. I would remind you that I am an automated system, not a human.
suggestion: Ask the bot who (or what) it is.

answer_guide: I would help explain the difference between business names and trade marks and explore how customers may be confused.
suggestion: Ask about another business using a similar name.

answer_guide: I would help explain what a cease and desist letter is and explore what the other side claims you have done.
suggestion: Ask about receiving or sending a cease and desist letter.

answer_guide: I would explain the importance of keeping your Address for Service up to date so you don't miss legal notices. I would provide the link to quickly update your contact details online.
suggestion: Ask how to update your address or email.

answer_guide: I would outline the different types of IP rights available to help you understand the differences.It depends on what you want to protect. If you describe your situation, I can help you narrow down the options and show you where to start.
suggestion: Ask which type of IP is right for your situation.

answer_guide: I would explore whether the conduct may relate to trade mark use or misleading impressions.
suggestion: Ask about competitors using your brand in advertising.

answer_guide: I would provide information about the application process and the importance of novelty/secrecy. I would also ask you to clarify which IP right you are discussing.
suggestion: Ask how you can keep your idea secret.

answer_guide: I would help explore whether confusion relates to branding, product look, marketing, or naming.
suggestion: Ask about customers confusing two brands or products.

answer_guide: I would provide the customer service contact details and operating hours. Make sure the user gets a clear and correct summary of what to tell the call center about their issue so they don’t need to expalin everythign again. Also tell them that the call center cannot provide personalised or legal advice.
suggestion: Ask for the phone number or contact hours.

answer_guide: I would explain what copyright protects and help explore whether the copied material may fall under copyright.
suggestion: Ask about someone using your creative work without permission.

answer_guide: I would clarify what a registered design covers and help explore similarities in overall appearance.
suggestion: Ask if you can enforce your ownership over the look of your product.

answer_guide: I would provide an overview of Design Rights and what they protect.
suggestion: Ask what a design right actually protects.

answer_guide: I would explore whether the domain resembles your brand and clarify whether it is a .au domain name.
suggestion: Ask about someone using a domain similar to your brand.

answer_guide: I would explain the function of IP Australia regarding enforcement. I would also ask you to clarify which IP right is involved.
suggestion: Ask what IP Australia can do to prevent infringement.

answer_guide: I would outline the examination process where IP Australia checks if your application meets the legal requirements. I would explain that you will receive a report if there are any issues to fix.
suggestion: Ask what happens after you apply.

answer_guide: I would explain what counterfeiting means and what information may help identify suspected counterfeit goods.
suggestion: Ask how to identify or report fake versions of your goods.

answer_guide: I would explain that the order of filing (e.g., Patent vs Design) matters due to novelty requirements. I would suggest seeking professional advice for complex filing strategies to ensure one application doesn't invalidate the other.
suggestion: Ask which IP right you should apply for first.

answer_guide: I would explain the importance and benefits of holding IP rights. I would also ask you to clarify which IP right you are interested in.
suggestion: Ask why a business should care about IP.

answer_guide: I would outline when importation may involve suspected infringement and ask about whether you hold a registered right.
suggestion: Ask about preventing infringing goods entering Australia.

answer_guide: I would provide an overview of how Indigenous Knowledge intersects with the IP system.
suggestion: Ask about protecting or enforcing Indigenous Knowledge.

answer_guide: I would provide relevant information about infringement procedures. I would also ask you to clarify which IP right is affected.
suggestion: Ask what to do if someone is copying your IP.

answer_guide: I would outline common types of helpful evidence for suspected infringement and what details may be useful.
suggestion: Ask what evidence is needed for an IP dispute.

answer_guide: I would state that IP rights are jurisdiction-specific and generally do not apply worldwide automatically. Most rights protect you only in Australia. If you need protection overseas, I can show you the pathways and tools that help you explore international options.
suggestion: Ask about protecting your IP overseas.

answer_guide: I would outline the costs associated with applying for and maintaining relevant IP rights. I would also ask you to clarify which specific IP right (e.g., Trade Mark, Patent) you are referring to.
suggestion: Ask about the cost of applying for IP - beyond just IP Australia fees.

answer_guide: I would provide an overview of IP Australia's functions. I would also ask you to clarify which IP right you need help with.
suggestion: Ask what IP Australia actually does.

answer_guide: I would provide a high-level overview of each IP right (Trade Marks, Patents, Designs, PBR).
suggestion: Ask what Intellectual Property actually is.

answer_guide: I would provide links to the specific legislation (such as the Trade Marks Act 1995). I would note that this is technical legal text and not a plain-english guide.
suggestion: Ask to see the specific legislation or Acts relating to IP rights

answer_guide: I would help clarify whether there is an existing licence and whether the use described appears outside its terms.
suggestion: Ask whether someone is using something beyond what you allowed.

answer_guide: I would provide an overview of the Madrid Protocol as a way to manage trade marks in multiple countries. I would explain that it is an international system used after you have an Australian application.
suggestion: Ask about the Madrid Protocol.

answer_guide: I would help identify what type of IP protection may apply and what information helps assess the situation.
suggestion: Ask about manufacturers creating copies of your product.

answer_guide: I would explore what materials or branding were taken and whether they may be protected by IP rights.
suggestion: Ask about a former worker using your IP without permission.

answer_guide: I would provide an overview of what each IP right protects and explain how they can be used together. Yes, sometimes using more than one type of IP gives stronger protection. Tell me what you’re working on, and I can help you explore the mix that might work.
suggestion: Ask if you can have more than one type of IP.

answer_guide: I would ask about the history of creation and any agreements, and outline general factors relevant to ownership disputes.
suggestion: Ask about disagreements over who owns the IP.

answer_guide: I would provide an overview of IP Australia's scope and clarify that we do not handle Copyright.
suggestion: Ask about IP rights not handled by IP Australia (like copyright, Gis etc).

answer_guide: I would outline common platform processes for reporting suspected infringement and ask which site you’re referring to.
suggestion: Ask about someone selling your product online without permission.

answer_guide: I would provide the direct link to the IP Australia online services portal. I would also ask if you are having trouble accessing an existing account.
suggestion: Ask where to log in to your account.

answer_guide: I would define OPI (Open to Public Inspection) as the stage where your application details become visible to the public. I would explain that this usually happens 18 months after filing for standard patents.
suggestion: Ask what OPI stands for.

answer_guide: I would explain that there is a formal Opposition Period where you can object to someone else's trade mark. I would highlight that this is a complex legal proceeding with strict deadlines.
suggestion: Ask how to stop someone else from registering a trade mark you don’t like.

answer_guide: I would provide an overview of the Patent system and what it protects. Most patents last up to 20 years. Some last up to 25 years. I can help you check the details for your type of invention.
suggestion: Ask what a patent protects.

answer_guide: I would help you understand what may indicate suspected patent infringement and clarify whether you hold a granted patent or application.
suggestion: Ask whether someone is using your invention.

answer_guide: I would provide an overview of what can and cannot be protected by a patent. Patents protect new and inventive ideas that you can show how they work. Ideas on their own can’t be patented. If you’re unsure, I can help you check.
suggestion: Ask what kind of things a patent can cover.

answer_guide: I would provide an overview of the Plant Breeder's Rights (PBR) system. A PBR protects new plant varieties and gives you control over who can grow and sell them. I can help you check if your variety might qualify.
suggestion: Ask what a Plant Breeder's Right is.

answer_guide: I would define Priority Date as the date used to establish who claimed an idea first. I would explain why this date is critical for determining if your IP is new.
suggestion: Ask what a priority date means.

answer_guide: I would explain that application fees are generally non-refundable once work has started. I would ask you to describe your specific situation so I can check if an exception applies.
suggestion: Ask if you can get a refund on your application.

answer_guide: I would provide an overview of IP Australia's role and the types of IP we administer.
suggestion: Ask what types of IP you can register.

answer_guide: I would provide an overview of the timeline for the application process. I would also ask you to specify which IP right you are interested in.
suggestion: Ask how long applying for IP takes.

answer_guide: I would explain that keeping your IP requires paying renewal fees at specific times. I would mention that missing these deadlines can lead to your IP expiring.
suggestion: Ask about fees for keeping your IP active.

answer_guide: I would explain that there is a 6-month grace period for late renewals, though it incurs extra monthly fees. I would warn that once this period ends, the right may be lost forever.
suggestion: Ask what happens if you miss a renewal deadline.

answer_guide: I would provide information about our search databases (like ATM for trade marks or AusPat for patents). I would explain that searching helps you see if your idea or brand is already taken.
suggestion: Ask how to search if your idea is taken.

answer_guide: I would explain that IP rights are assets that can be sold or transferred. I would guide you to the Assignment form needed to officially record the new owner.
suggestion: Ask how to transfer ownership of your IP.

answer_guide: I would discuss platform reporting features and explore what IP right may apply to the copied content.
suggestion: Ask about someone copying your content on social media.

answer_guide: I would acknowledge you want to speak to a person. I would provide the phone number (1300 65 10 10) and operating hours for our customer service team. I would tell them what to tell the customer service team so they can understand the issue quickly.
suggestion: Ask to speak to a real person.

answer_guide: I would outline general indicators of suspected trade mark infringement and ask you for examples of how the other party is using the brand.
suggestion: Ask how to tell if someone is using your brand without permission.

answer_guide: I would explain that trade marks are categorised into 45 classes of goods and services. I would point you to the classification search tool (picklist) to help you find the right ones for your business.
suggestion: Ask about trade mark classes or goods and services.

answer_guide: I would define TM Headstart as a pre-assessment service that gives you a quick answer (in 5 days) on whether your trade mark is likely to be approved before you pay the full fee.
suggestion: Ask what the Headstart service is.

answer_guide: I would provide an overview of what typically cannot be registered as a trade mark. Signs that are too descriptive, common or offensive can’t be registered. If you tell me what you want to protect, I can help you understand the risks.
suggestion: Ask what things cannot be registered as a trade mark.

answer_guide: I would explain the difference between a trade mark, a business name, and a domain name. A business name and domain name don’t give you rights over your brand. Only a trade mark does. If you want help working out what you need, just tell me your situation.
suggestion: Ask about how business names are protected.

answer_guide: I would provide an overview of the Trade Mark system and what it protects. A trade mark protects the sign people use to recognise your business, like a name or logo. If you’re unsure whether yours can be a trade mark, I can help you check.
suggestion: Ask what a trade mark protects.

answer_guide: A trade mark can last forever if you renew it every 10 years. I can show you where to check your renewal dates.
suggestion: Ask how and when a trade mark expires.

answer_guide: I would explain the concept of parallel imports and ask how the goods were originally sold.
suggestion: Ask whether someone can resell your branded goods in Australia.

answer_guide: I would explain what an unjustified threat is in general terms and help clarify the claim made against you.
suggestion: Ask about dealing with a threat of IP action.
